results.content:
Unfortunately, technical issues, inconsistent delivery, raw end-product, and missing content - the sheer amount of which make them very hard to ignore - make this Docker course miss its goal. The author has a good outline to re-build this course around in the future if interested, though. But, in its current form the Docker beginner should look at other course options.

After completing every section of this course, here are some of the most notable challenges with it:
1. Several sections are extremely repetitive, and sections of audio appear to have been re-used on purpose.

2. The initial modules are unnecessarily long, and with explanations that do not add details around the few commands presented.

3. There are discrepancies between what is being said and what is being typed.

4. The author uses layman terms for technical details; this is not necessarily bad, but he is inconsistent on doing this throughout sections.

5. Many section titles do not match their content. The contents of a number of sections are repeated under incorrect titles, and this makes some sections completely miss material they are supposed to cover.

6. Audio is not edited, it is repetitive in places and muffled in others. There are background office and street sounds, awkward pauses, unexpected cuts, silent sections, and sentences restarted.

7. There is inconsistent attention to the OS platforms being discussed. The Linux installation is sub-optimal and incomplete. For example, there is no acknowledgement that on a standard Linux install the Docker daemon in Linux binds to a Unix socket that by default is owned by root; this fact makes sudo the way to execute the Docker CLI commands, although there are ways around this.

8. The author uses "here" to call attention to things on the screen without obvious highlights to call attention to where "here" is. Referencing a line number in the editor on some of these instances would have been better.

9. In at least the Docker Compose and Docker Cloud modules there are cut and broken videos.

10. Several slides have typos.

11. The author relies on magic commands and options on occasions. Some examples are more complicated than they have to be just to demonstrate a basic concept; for example, a number of the applications (images) used do require some configuration that a beginner is most like to miss.
results.content_html:

There is some very useful information, but there are many sloppy mistakes.  As a clear example, there are Mac-specific titles given to Windows-specific content and vice-versa.   Multiple videos are titled "Introduction".  

The second small gripe is that often the video displays a full screen instead of just the terminal in which work is being done.  At the max available resolution of 720p, it's not a clear picture of what is being typed.

The author would do well to have someone act as a pre-release reviewer.
